prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal is to detect the far-IR dust continuum. We do not expect major emission lines in this window. So we will use the default frequency setting for continuum in Band 7.
We request an angular resolution of 0.5 arcsec, to match the typical resolution of ground-based optical observations. We do not expect the high-redshift target to be substantially larger than this.

NOTE: All the technical justifications of the science goals are identical. Although our galaxy targets are at different redshifts, the flux of the dust emission is insensitive to redshift because of the negative K-correction. Therefore all the science goals have identical sensitivity requirements.
We will use ALMA Band 7 to detect the far-IR continuum from the GRB host galaxies. Band 7 is chosen because of its great sensitivity to dust with opacity laws of beta ~ 1.0-1.5. We will adopt the nominal frequency of Band 7. In the Scientific Justification, we argue that we need to detect a 0.3 mJy source at 345 GHz. This corresponds to an obscured star formation rate of 6 to 60 Msun/yr, which is comparable to the extinction corrected star formation rates derived from optical observations. We request a uniform sensitivity across our targets to avoid biases in the optical determinations of the star formation rates.
We request S/N = 7 for the targeted 0.3 mJy for robust detections. This will still lead to an acceptable S/N of >4 when the target is slightly extended comparing to our proposed synthesized beam size. Therefore, the requested rms noise is 43 uJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Studies of distant starburst galaxies hosting GRBs offer unique insights into extreme star-forming regions during early epochs. In particular, 25-40% of all GRBs show a suppressed optical to x-ray ratio in the afterglow. A likely explanation is that they originate in dusty galaxies, which are commonly missed in optical surveys. We have carried out a successful program in ALMA Cycle 0 to observe the galaxy hosting the dark GRB 080607 at z = 3.036. We obtained a marginal detection of its 345 GHZ continuum, placing it at the faintest end of the dusty galaxy population. This indicates that the large extinction (Av ~ 3) in the afterglow is confined along a dusty sight line, contrary to the expectation of the host galaxy itself being dusty. Here we propose to conduct a systematic study of nine galaxies hosting dust-obscured GRBs at z > 1.5 based on observations of their 345 GHz continuum. All nine galaxies have spectroscopic redshifts to confirm that the suppressed optical fluxes are indeed due to extinction, rather than IGM absorption. The proposed imaging will allow us to characterize the global dust content of the host galaxies in a broader context of the dusty galaxy population.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: The cycle-2 project 2013.1.00941.S is a filler program. The present cycle-3 proposal contains all targets in the cycle-2 one, and has new sources. Our cycle-0 project 2011.0.00101.S (published) contains shallower observations of one of the targets in the present cycle-3 proposal.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Astronomy & Astrophysics, Chicago, University of
